author: thezim
body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Extracting [Windows build ZIP](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/download/v7.1.5/PowerShell-7.1.5-win-x64.zip) produces files names with backslashes on MacOS. This occurs with the built in Archive Utility.app as well as msbuild [Unzip](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/msbuild/unzip-task?view=vs-2019) task. This does not occur with the the command line utility unzip.

A little research points to the ZIP file not being [backwards compatible](https://superuser.com/questions/1382839/zip-files-expand-with-backslashes-on-linux-no-subdirectories).

I understand handling of the backslash character should be handled in the archive utility. However given the of how this affects the MacOS built in utility and how pervasive it is perhaps it can be looked at in the spirit of being a good citizen of the ZIP standard.

I understand if this may be an issue with the underlying compression utility/framework. I was unable to follow the build process used to create the ZIP. 


### Expected behavior

```console
Extracting Windows build ZIP file created proper folder structure.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Extraction creates file names with backslashes instead for sub folders.
```


### Error details

```console
No error occurs.
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Not applicable.
```


### Visuals

_No response_

comments.author: thezim
comments.body: If `Compress-Archive` was used this issue was fixed with PowerShell/Microsoft.PowerShell.Archive#62.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body:
It's called in the release build from here:
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/57f4ccd1fcbf15a2c143007102fb81a79decf3ea/tools/releaseBuild/azureDevOps/templates/windows-packaging.yml#L273

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body:
Probably updating line 254 from 
```yaml
  - powershell: |
```
to
```yaml
  - pwsh: |
```

Will resolve the issue.  If someone, submits a PR and mentions me, I'll start a test build.

I'm assuming that the version of PowerShell 7 that comes on the agent already has a fixed archive module.

comments.author: thezim
comments.body: @TravisEz13  PowerShell [7.0.0](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/download/v7.0.0/PowerShell-7.0.0-win-x64.zip) came with version 1.2.5 of Microsoft.PowerShell.Archive. Issue was fixed in 1.2.3 version of the model so your proposed fix should work.
